title: 114_s1968
content: The Act may be cited as the "Business Supply Chain Transparency on Trafficking and Slavery Act of 2015". It includes findings and the sense of Congress. Congress finds that in 2014, the Department of Labor identified 136 goods from 74 countries made by forced labor and child labor. The United States, as the world's largest importer, faces increasing demands for information on human rights impact of products. Consumers lack standing to enforce provisions of the Smoot Hawley Tariff Act of 1930 in US courts. The Smoot Hawley Tariff Act of 1930 prohibits importation of goods made with forced or convict labor, with exceptions for goods not produced in sufficient quantities in the US. There have been fewer than 40 enforcement actions in the past 80 years under this provision. Federal mechanisms to prevent and punish forced labor, slavery, human trafficking, and child labor in commerce are lacking. The Trafficking Victims Protection Reauthorization Act of 2003 and the Trafficking Victims Protection Act of 2005 aim to address severe forms of trafficking in persons and commercial sex acts in Federal contracts. The worst forms of child labor in the stream of commerce face challenges due to limited scope, broad expectations, and lack of information on goods produced along tainted supply chains imported by the United States. The Trafficking Victims Protection Act of 2005 criminalizes severe forms of trafficking in persons and forced labor in Federal contracts. Executive Orders 13126 and 13627 prohibit the acquisition of products produced by forced or indentured child labor. Executive Order 13627 and the National Defense Authorization Act for Fiscal Year 2013 have banned Federal contractors from engaging in trafficking-related activities such as charging labor recruitment fees, confiscating passports, and using fraudulent recruitment practices. Federal contractors, subcontractors, and their employees must adhere to anti-trafficking compliance plans, including a complaint mechanism and measures to prevent trafficking in persons. Congress recognizes forced labor, slavery, human trafficking, and child labor as severe forms of abuse for profit. The legislative framework to prevent abuse for commercial profit is inadequate in the United States. Legislation is needed to inform consumers about products free of child labor, forced labor, slavery, and human trafficking. Public disclosures can help businesses and consumers avoid supporting these practices. Consumers can prevent supporting crimes by avoiding tainted products in the supply chains. SEC. 3. DISCLOSURE OF INFORMATION RELATING TO EFFORTS TO COMBAT FORCED LABOR, SLAVERY, TRAFFICKING, AND CHILD LABOR. The Securities Exchange Act of 1934 is amended to require covered issuers to disclose efforts to combat forced labor, slavery, trafficking, and child labor. Regulations will be promulgated within a year of the enactment of the Business Supply Chain Transparency on Trafficking and Slavery Act of 2015. The Securities Exchange Act of 1934 amendment requires covered issuers to annually disclose measures taken to address forced labor, slavery, human trafficking, and child labor in their supply chain. This disclosure must include information on policies implemented to combat these issues. The covered issuer must disclose if they have a policy to address forced labor, slavery, human trafficking, and child labor in their supply chain, including actions taken. The covered issuer must disclose policies on prohibiting employees from engaging in commercial sex acts with minors and efforts to address risks of forced labor, slavery, human trafficking, and child labor in the product supply chain. The covered issuer must disclose risks in the supply chain and efforts to eliminate them, specify if evaluation was done by a third party, and mention consultation with labor organizations or workers. The disclosure must specify consultation with labor organizations or workers and cover entities within the supply chain. The covered issuer must ensure audits of suppliers in the supply chain to investigate working conditions, labor practices, and risks of forced labor, slavery, and human trafficking. The covered issuer must audit suppliers in the supply chain to investigate labor practices, including forced labor, slavery, and human trafficking, and ensure compliance with their policies. Suppliers must attest to ethical manufacturing and labor recruitment practices. The covered issuer must ensure compliance with laws regarding forced labor, slavery, human trafficking, and child labor in recruitment. Internal accountability standards and reporting procedures are maintained for entities failing to meet these standards within the supply chain. The covered issuer must train employees and management on issues related to forced labor, slavery, human trafficking, and child labor in supply chain management to mitigate risks. The covered issuer must ensure that labor recruitment practices at all suppliers comply with policies to eliminate exploitive labor practices contributing to forced labor, slavery, human trafficking, and child labor. Compliance includes audits of labor recruiters and disclosure of audit results. The covered issuer must provide remedial action for victims of forced labor, slavery, human trafficking, and child labor in the supply chain to prevent recurrence. Information must be disclosed on the company website. The regulations require covered issuers to disclose information on their website under the label 'Global Supply Chain Transparency'. The Commission will also publish a list of covered issuers on its website. The regulations mandate covered issuers to disclose measures taken to address forced labor, slavery, human trafficking, and child labor in their supply chain. Additionally, they must compile and submit this information as required. The term 'covered issuer' refers to an issuer with annual global receipts exceeding $100,000,000. 'Forced labor', 'slavery', and 'human trafficking' are defined as labor practices violating national and international standards. The Victims Protection Act of 2000 (Public Law 106-386) includes criminal provisions related to slavery and human trafficking under chapter 77 of title 18, United States Code. Remedial action refers to activities or systems implemented by an issuer to address non-compliance identified through monitoring or verification. The term 'supply chain' for a covered issuer means all labor recruiters, suppliers, component parts, and raw materials used in manufacturing products. 'The worst forms of child labor' refer to child labor violating national laws. 'The worst forms of child labor' refers to child labor that violates national and international standards, including International Labor Organization Convention No. 182.
